review_blob:
Another "different" beer making use of local ingredients. The salicorne grows in the Somme marshland. In Britain we would call it samphire. 

Unfortunately unlike the de la Somme LArgousette beer I dont think the salicorne really adds anything. Maybe it makes it extra bitter. Possibly a little salty. Also a little grassy but basically nothing outstanding.

Beer pours well. Pale gold possibly a slightly green tint. My 33cl bottle was rather lively despite being past its June 2014 use by date.

Pours dark brown / black. Slight pale brown head. Aroma reminds me of the canned liquid malt you could buy from Boots in the 1970s for home brewing. Not a good memory! in fact it tastes a little like that although sweeter. I would never have bought this beer - it was given to me several years ago and I have kept putting off trying it. Until drinking I hadnt noticed it was a low alcohol beer. Too sweet for me but I get the festive idea.

Sweet then bitter. Got blackcurrant and raspberry. Aroma not great. Taste did vary a lot in my mouth. Sometimes a little sour. Been sitting unmoved in my cellar for a couple of years. Bought in Saint-Valery-sur-Somme with a consume by date of 02/14
